div1.p: Hench requests that Tate carefully read his whole questionnaire before beginning to answer the questions.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Paul L. Tate, July 19, 1954
div1.opener:
July 19, 1954
Mr. Paul Tate,
1530 Tyler Street,
Berkeley 3, California
Dear Mr. Tate:
div1.p:
I received from Miss Bruce the corrected transcription of our
interview of June 21, 1954. I have carefully studied it and your old
letters to me. As a result, I have written down many, many questions
and comments arranged under 113 numbered questions.

I would appreciate it tremendously and be most grateful to you
if you would, during the next days and weeks, give me as much of your
time and effort as it will take (and it will be a lot, I know) to answer
all of these questions. Aside from Lambert (whose memory is poor) and
Handberry whom I have not (yet) gotten much out of, you are the only living
eye-witness to these stirring events, at least so far as I know.

Now, my main concern is that you will look at this formidable
list of questions, throw up your hands in despair, and regard the task
as an impossible one. I do wish you would not be panicked by the number
of questions I'm sending you.

Please, first of all, read over the entire questionnaire before
you try to answer a single question. You will find much overlapping because
I wrote them as they came to me and often decided to amplify a question
long after I had asked it first.

Although you may, on first reading, think you cannot answer many
of the questions, if you mull over the matter, it may be surprising how things
may come back to you. I'm hoping my photographs and comments will help to
jog your memory. Please don't try to start answering any questions until
you have read the whole thing over once or twice and looked at the various
“enclosures.”

I have a copy of this questionnaire so you can keep this one and
make on it whatever scribbled notes you wish so as to help you when you start
to dictate or type your answers. Doubtless you can combine in one, answers
to more than one question. You have said that you did not think you wanted
to use the services of a professional stenographer, such as Miss Bruce, but
would prefer to type the answers yourself at home and at your own convenience.
I hate to put you to so much trouble. But I agree that it might be much
easier for you in the long run. Also, I am worried lest the comprehensive-
ness of this questionnaire frighten you off or tire you out. Could you just
decide to “take it easy” in replying and cover just so much ground each day
as you have the desire and the time?

I hate to bother you like this. But if you do see fit to help me,
you will be implementing, for medical history and for all time, your admiration
for your medical colleagues (Reed, et al) who did so much for us all. Also,
you will be making a personal contribution which will earn you a place in my
book, for I shall certainly refer to you often and thank you publicly and
most gratefully.

As for answering these questions, please always number your answers
as per the question number. If you can do so, please keep a carbon of your
answers so that we can correspond further as necessary. But if it is too
much trouble for you to make a carbon for yourself, send me your answers, and
I will have an ozalid copy of each page (of your answers) made here and return
them to you to keep.

You might prefer to wait until you have answered all the questions
before sending any answers to me. But I do wish you would send your answers
to me in batches or sections, for several reasons. First, I can be digesting
your answers as they come along and looking up data which might be helpful to
each of us; secondly, if anything happened to you before finishing all of the
questions, your unmailed answers might never reach me.

If you choose to pass by the more difficult questions and answer the
easier ones first, please do so. Just stick to the appropriate numbers, and I can
re-assemble numerically later. In any event, the most of the questions are
separate and disconnected.

I wish, of course, that you and I could “visit” with each other for an
hour two daily. Then we could simply converse over this, my secretary could
transcribe our remarks, or we could have them on a machine, and no trouble to
you. Incidentally, if you thought it impossible to dictate or type answers
yourself, would you consider dictating them to a machine? Have you used a
tape recorded or any other type? I am so anxious to get your answers to these
questions; perhaps we could borrow or rent a machine in your home town so that
you could use it at your leisure. But perhaps, as you told me, it would be
easiest in the long run, if you just typed two or three pages yourself whenever
the mood strikes you.

Believe me, Mr. Tate, I and all of the relatives of these fine men
of whom we write, will be most grateful for your help. Please let me know
if there is anything I have which you would like to borrow: The Senate Document
822, Agramonte's article in Military Surgeon, Kelly's book, or anything else
I've mentioned or any photo you may want to see (I have many).
Keep the two current maps of Havana if you wish.

Thanks just loads for the help you have already given me. I only
hope you will react to my questions as did Generals Kean and Truby. After they
got at it, they found it gave them great pleasure and a great sense of usefulness
as they recalled old times and helped me record them.

closer.seg:
P. S. I am having the Pinar del Rio photos copied and will send them soon
(Enclosures fla. 3, 4, 5) P. S. H.
